message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of acute intermittent abdominal pain, radiating to the right lower quadrant, with vomiting and drawing up of knees to chest is suggestive of Meckel diverticulum, which is the most common underlying cause of this condition. The ultrasound findings of concentric rings of bowel also support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely causes of this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of acute intermittent umbilical abdominal pain, vomiting, and right lower abdominal pain every 15-30 minutes suggests Meckel diverticulum, the most common underlying cause. The concentric rings of bowel on ultrasound are consistent with the presence of Meckel diverticulum. Malrotation with volvulus may also present with abdominal pain, vomiting, and hemoglobin concentration can be low, but the pain is not usually intermittent and tends to persist. Intestinal polyps and intestinal adhesions are less common causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute appendicitis, and among the options, Meckel diverticulum is the most common underlying cause of acute pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen in a young child. Meckel diverticulum is a congenital remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct and can cause acute abdominal pain similar to appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history of similar episodes suggest Meckel diverticulum as the most common underlying cause. Malrotation with volvulus can present with similar symptoms but is less common. Intestinal polyps and adhesions are less likely to present with acute intermittent umbilical abdominal pain. The ultrasound findings of concentric rings of bowel suggest small bowel obstruction, which can be caused by Meckel diverticulum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the periumbilical tenderness and drawing knees to chest, suggest Meckel diverticulum, which is the most common underlying cause of this condition. Malrotation with volvulus would have shown abnormalities in the position of the intestines on ultrasound, and intestinal adhesions usually occur after surgery or inflammation. Intestinal polyps can cause similar symptoms but are less common in this age group.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the question stem suggest possible Meckel's diverticulum, which is a congenital abnormality. The ultrasound finding of concentric rings of bowel is also suggestive of an obstructing structure in the small intestine, which is consistent with a Meckel's diverticulum. The other options may also cause abdominal pain/vomiting, but they are less common in the pediatric population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history of the patient suggest Meckel diverticulum, which is the most common cause of acute intermittent umbilical abdominal pain in pediatric patients. Malrotation with volvulus is also a possible cause but it presents with bilious vomiting, and intestinal polyps and adhesions are less common overall. The findings on ultrasound support the diagnosis of Meckel diverticulum, which can present with concentric rings of bowel.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including umbilical pain that radiates to the right lower abdomen, drawing up knees to the chest, and a history of similar episodes in the past, suggest Meckel diverticulum. The ultrasound findings of concentric rings of bowel also support this diagnosis. Malrotation with volvulus may cause similar symptoms but is less common and is usually associated with bilious vomiting. Intestinal polyps and adhesions are unlikely causes in this age group.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with Meckel diverticulum, which is a true diverticulum that occurs because it is lined with all three layers of the intestinal wall. Malrotation with volvulus is a medical emergency that presents with bilious vomiting and requires immediate surgical intervention. Intestinal polyps and intestinal adhesions can also cause abdominal pain, but they are less common in children and have different presentations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation of acute intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and periumbilical tenderness with no masses palpated suggest Meckel diverticulum as the most common underlying cause. The concentric rings of bowel on ultrasound also support this diagnosis. Malrotation with volvulus would present with bilious vomiting and may have a palpable mass. Intestinal polyps and intestinal adhesions would not present with the characteristic acute intermittent abdominal pain and drawing up of the knees.
